This is another fine lecture on Counting Rules by professor Marten van Dijk. An introduction to Probability and Statistics class should be a requirement for Discreet Mathematics. On the contrary, the MIT student should be somewhat familiar with Probability and Statistics from  high school.

In the two examples following the full house example, there really isn't any increased clarity offered by the attempt to use bijection or k-to-1 function. In the end the validity of the function mapping rests on the reasoning provided, which itself already does the counting.  I believe the idea of using a function to map one set to another is to abstract specific details away from the problem and so offer greater clarity with the resulting simplified set (the codomain). This was powerfully demonstrated in mapping all possible subsets of a set of size n to possible bit-sequences of length n in the previous lecture. However in those examples in this lecture, the codomain was not specified precisely. Moreover, the direction of the function mapping was not consistent, as one might observe from the 2 pairs example.
Great lecture, thanks!

For the number of hands with every other suit, do we divide by 2 or divide by 4!...?

It is 2 since we can have only 2 different cards with the same suit and for them we have 2! exchange possibilities which is equal to 2. All the other cards by the counting rule must represent different suits.
